title: Chronic venous insufficiency: Causes, symptoms and risks
body: Chronic venous insufficiency (CVI) is the most common vascular disease worldwide, and early treatment can help avoid significant pain and discomfort.Forty million Americans suffer from chronic venous insufficiency, yet only 6% to 8% receive treatment.  Center for Vein Restoration, the DC area's clinical leader in vein care, are experts in the treatment of venous insufficiency. , joined ABC7 to talk more about the disease's progression and how important it is to seek early treatment.Veins return blood to the heart from all over the body. In the legs, blood needs to flow upward via the veins. Calf muscles and the other leg muscles contract to squeeze the veins and push the blood upward to reach the heart.CVI happens when leg veins are not working effectively, making it difficult for blood to return to the heart from the legs. CVI causes blood to "pool" or collect in these veins. This pooling is called stasis.Leg veins have tiny one-way valves to keep the blood flowing upward instead of down. When these valves fail to work properly, the backflow of blood can cause a variety of health problems, including leg swelling and heaviness, aching, rashes, recurrent skin infection, chronic wounds, bulging veins, and skin color changes.Chronic venous insufficiency occurs when leg valves become damaged, allowing the blood to leak backward.  may occur due to:
